segments.text: Then I was in that Director of Combat Developments for the remainder of my time in Doctrine, for the remainder of my time at Fort Sill.
Actually, the title changed because that directorate went from under the new Combat Developments Command at Fort Belvoir, Virginia, but it was the same job.
The name changed.
The function and my job remained the same.
And what did you do as the director?

Our mission in the Office of Combat Developments and Doctrine, and later the Combat Developments Command, it was called, Field Artillery, we were to develop the doctrine and material requirements for the future, for the Field Artillery.
In other words, we would ask ourselves the question, how should the field artillery be organized, how should it be equipped, and how should it fight in the future?
And I'll tell you, that's a very great challenge to take those questions and work them.
And it was one of the most interesting jobs that I
that I ever had.

Now, later on in my career as a general officer, I was deputy commander of the Combat Development Command near Washington, looking at that total picture and looking back at some of the work we did down there seven years before, six or seven years before.
And that was an interesting experience, too, to be able to go from the
basic organization and developments up to the top and look at it from both ends.
How many did you have on the staff helping you with this with this chore?
At Fort Selle?
Yeah.
30 some odd officers with the supporting non-coms and civilian people 30 odd I forget just how many it was pretty sizable organization.
And what would you do sort of sit down and have seminars on particular
Well, of course, we worked hand in glove with the field artillery school, particularly on doctrine, because they're teaching doctrine, and we were going to develop new doctrine.
In other words, when you get new capabilities, you have to have new ways of doing things, and that becomes the doctrine.
Now, the material side of it really is harder, I mean simpler, than the doctrine side of it.
You kind of sometimes get into the question of the chicken and the egg,
One, when you ask how should we be equipped, maybe you'd like to know how do we want to operate or accomplish, and then decide how to equip.
Or you let the other approach, and it varies.
The state of the art will permit us now to have, let's say, a cannon or an artillery weapon and shoot 75 miles.
Well, up to now, 20 miles has been the number.
Okay, what
Should we take advantage of this state of the art?
If so, what would we use that weapon for?
And how, then, should we involve a doctrine for its use?
What should be the doctrine for its use?
I just gave you an example.
One of the things that we tied into was taking advantage of computers to do the fire direction, fire data computing for the field artillery weapons.
And we initiated that there.
As I say, it was slow to come to fruition.
We also, by the way, initiated the requirement which finally was approved for what is now known as the Lance Missile.
We wrote the first piece of paper on it.
That was too slow in being, it's just been recently been put in the category, in the inventory also.
We're talking 20 years ago.
And what was the difference between the Lance Missile and the other... Well, the Lance Missile was this weapon that would shoot 20... We knew we could now shoot a 75-mile.
We used to have the old Honest John rockets that shot about 20.
And our concept of the Lance Missile in the beginning was that it be primarily a nuclear weapon and it be
A division weapon.
The division commander, you have a unit in a division.
And, of course, you could have some in corps.
So that the division commander could influence the battlefield out to 75 miles.
Well, the concept has been changed, not by the Army, but by the Department of Defense twice.
It's no longer a division weapon.
It's no longer primarily in a nuclear weapon.
Really, it is dual capable, and we had it dual capable too.
And the character of it changed at least twice that I know of.
But at least that concept is now a reality.
And what is it today?
Today it's a core weapon only.
In other words, the division commander will not have it.
It will be controlled by the commander above him.
That's why.
Is the range still 75?
I don't know what the specific range is, but I think it's basically the same.
As a matter of fact, I think they increased it.
I'm sure they did, as I recall.
They increased it since I left the Army.
That was another major change.
Of course, when you increase that requirement for range, and they did that by making it a core weapon, then you change the, everything's got to be changed.
The screws and the nuts and the bolts and the power unit and the guidance system and everything.
And tactics also.
So it's no wonder we go 20 years to get it on the field.
Besides these two, the use of the computer and the Lance missile, were there other major advances that you people were working on?
Oh, yes.
We had, I think we should go to lunch, and then I'd like to discuss the most exciting, I think, of the era.
What was that?
But I will mention that we did have a new family of,
field artillery cannon weapons that we were proposing, and most of those are in the inventory.
But the exciting one I want to mention is the aerial artillery, the artillery to support the air assault division when the Army took to the air in helicopters, and I'd like to discuss that with you.
Okay, can we read back some of that?
Well, we were talking about four major advancements.
The computer, the lance missile, the field artillery cannons, and the air artillery.
Oh, yeah.
I wanted to get into that.
Yeah, you were going to talk about the field artillery and the air artillery.
Yes, I wanted to get into that aerial artillery and just mention before I do that, of course, one of our important areas of
The shoot, move, and communicate was communications and, of course, mobility.
And we did also state the requirements for, and we now have in the field, the field radios that we envisioned then for field artillery.
A number of the weapons were self-propelled and therefore self-mobile.
But the newest concept in mobility, moving, was the helicopter.
You know, the helicopter had proven very useful in Korea, basically as an evacuation vehicle.
But we made great strides with the helicopter, and we had some very fine ones.
And so we conceived of an artillery unit equipped with rockets mounted on helicopters.
And we developed an organization and equipment list for that and submitted it to higher headquarters.
And they didn't act upon that because coincidentally, I think, they just sent it back saying that the Army's created a new board called the Air Mobility Board.
to investigate the use of helicopters across the board and other aircraft by the Army in general.
And so your recommendation returned for consideration in that process.
This started in 19, that was 1962.
Actually, this board convened, it became known as the House Board, it's a rather famous board, because it did result in a sort of a revolutionary doctrine for the use of aircraft for the Army.
How's H-O-U-S-E?
H-O-W-Z-E. And I was fortunate enough to have been a member of that board, and I took that little package, but of course what we dealt with was much larger.
But in the end of the actions, we did wind up with such a unit.
We did wind up also with recommendations for a division and separate units that were oriented toward the use, equipped to use helicopters and to take maximum advantage of air mobility.
You know, when you introduce, it's a funny thing, as we go along in the developments of capabilities for war,
Occasionally there's a significant jump, like the nuclear weapon, for example, and firepower.
Mobility, we felt, could be influenced dramatically by intelligent use of helicopters.
So we wound up basically with a division equipped with these and the units within the division, which included the artillery.
battalion of these rocket helicopter unit, helicopter outfit.
And then we had direct support units with the regular cannon, but their mobility was provided with a larger helicopter.
This then became, it was approved by the Secretary of Defense.
He's the one who directed this study we made.
Great.
And Mr. McNamara had approved this for testing.

I left Fort Sill to go to this trial division which was then called the 11th Air Assault Division and was one of those I think fortunate people who had the opportunity to be with it to get it organized and trained and tested and the final test well before approval came in the Carolinas on maneuvers and
And when was that?
That was in October, November of 63.
Okay.
Okay.
And Mr. McNamara approved the organization that basically we tested there, which included this division and other units.
And tell me what equipment you had in that division.
Well, we had, I'd like to mention that,

after we get them in Vietnam because the final approval within some, not too many months after approval of these organizations, President Johnson decided to go into Vietnam in strength and we were alerted to go.
We were the first full division to go.
Now there were a couple of brigade combat teams that went over in advance of us.
We had, as a result of these
studies, tests, we were deployed with roughly 450 aircraft.
Most of those were helicopters.
What type?
We had what's called the Huey, which was the workhorse, basic troop carrier.
It's also, that's it.
It was also the vehicle that we hung these rockets on.
It was also the vehicle that basically carried the reconnaissance elements in there
weaponry.
Then we had the little H-13 helicopter, it's a little two-seated helicopter which was used for light reconnaissance and observation.
Then we had the heavy, heavier medium, it's a medium helicopter, CH-47, which lifted the artillery and we developed means for moving, no that's still the Huey, like we could move an artillery piece

its ammunition and its crew in one of those but actually we would sling the weapon and the ammunition under it and the reason we did that was because it was much quicker than loading it in the aircraft and out and the reason you wanted to be very quick is when you unloaded and then you know where you were vulnerable vulnerable to enemy action you wanted to get it off and get that aircraft out as fast as possible
and we had in the division a troop of twin engine reconnaissance aircraft and initially we had a squadron or battalion of light transport aircraft fixed wing those were later

determined to be an Air Force mission and we turned them over to an Air Force unit and they supported us but anyway all this added up gave us tremendous capability to do our all the functions on the battlefield well what it sounds like to me and correct me if I'm wrong is that what you did in 1961 and 1962 was basically change the function of the helicopter to a combat aircraft
I'm just sort of a surprise.
That's true.
From 62 and 3 and 4, yes.
That's absolutely true.
So you were right in the forefront of this combat use of the helicopter.
I was among those few that really went through all phases of this.
There were a lot involved at some phase or another, yes.
That's true.
And, of course, the helicopter had been looked upon up until then as a transport aircraft and an evacuation aircraft.
But there's a lot of difference between moving in a helicopter or a group of a bunch of helicopters and maneuvering in them.
And of course, we could get into any amount of detail on that aspect of it.
But suffice it to say that we were equipped to perform really all functions of combat with aircraft.

although we did have units with vehicles so that you know we could carry the heavy loads and catch up and build up but we could go into a combat situation relying entirely on aircraft initially and then when you in June of 1964 when you became the commanding officer of the 11th air assault division artillery you were the first division to use helicopters in this sense that's that's right we were the first to have them organized
You were the first helicopter division.
Yes, we were the first, that's right, in the first air assault division.
That's fantastic.
The first division to have anything like that organization.
Who was your commanding general?
The commanding general was General H.W.
O'Conard who was a brilliant thinker, tactician, leader.
and I consider myself very fortunate to have been associated with him.
You recall in the Battle of the Bulge when General McCulloch answered the German demand for surrender by saying nuts?
The story is that Harry Cunard was the G3 of that time and he's actually the one who said send this message.
But he did a brilliant job there and later

after we came both came back from vietnam he left the division before i did uh he was appointed commander of the combat developments command near washington there because of his great capacity for thinking into guiding new ideas and then when i came back after a while after i got back oh after about a year i was assigned as his deputy in that command
he's a deputy commander.
Well this is really a great change then for the use of helicopters and this is probably a great honor for you wasn't it to be to be the uh commanding officer of of that division?
Well I was commanding officer of the division artillery.
Right yeah and how many how many other divisions?
You see sure how many other colonels were there?
Oh there were there were quite a number you see that division consisted of three brigades

a division artillery all commanded by colonels, an aviation group commanded by a colonel, and then there were other separate units of battalion size commanded by lieutenant colonels, and then of course the subordinate units of those majors won.
So there were three generals and I guess six colonels in that division, five colonels in that division.
So you were right in the forefront then.
I happen to be, that's one of those matters of being in the right place at the right time for advantage.
The advantage being that I was in the most interesting outfit to come down the pike since I'd been in the Army.
And when we went to Vietnam, we couldn't have come close to doing what we did in Vietnam without that capability.
We were freed from the terrain.
That's the main thing, you see.
Well, you went to Vietnam then in January of 1965.

that's no in uh September of 65 isn't it January quarter assist oh it does okay well you were made assistant division commander in January of 65 then were you sent to Vietnam in September of 65 this should read uh 66 we went to uh
We went to Vietnam in September of 66.
No, you're right, 65.
In September of 65, and I was made assistant division commander in January of 66.
So two months later, I moved from division artillery commander to assistant division commander and was nominated for promotion to brigadier general.
There were two assistant division commanders, one assistant for logistics,

I was the operations assistant well let's talk about Vietnam are we ready to talk about that okay good what were your feelings when when you got your orders to go to Vietnam to a new theater of combat well the uh I felt it was the thing to do because of course we've been following the situation and I guess this was no great surprise that we were going to

the U.S. was going to send a major force into Vietnam it was a little bit of a surprise I guess that we were chosen to be the the ones to lead off well we really weren't the lead I've got to give credit to the first brigade of the 101st airborne division and of the 73rd separate brigade who went over being smaller lighter they got there before we did
But nevertheless, I thought it was the right thing to do as an individual.
I'd spent many years being a student of this communist effort that appeared to be aimed at taking over the world, and they'd have to take us over before they ever accomplished that.
And I basically felt that the further away from home we could defeat their efforts, the better.
And I'd rather see it defeated now in my time than to have my boys inherit the job, for example.
And I felt it very essential that we keep it away from this hemisphere in any case.
So I thought it was a logical decision.
And so in other words, you were pretty eager to get in the combat.
Yes, sir.
I thought it was the right thing to do.
OK. What were the conditions like when you landed?
and where did you go?
where were you stationed?
we went into what was called the Highlands area okay two corps?

third corps okay third corps and uh as you know Pleiku was the capital of that region and uh we went in our base camp was at Anke which was uh oh about 20 miles inland from the uh China Sea there to go
But we immediately started operating, of course.
Initially, constructing the base and getting it in condition, we sent out one brigade at a time and operations, and eventually we got to the position where we had all three brigades out.
The base became just a place like, you know, to store things and to have the support troops that aren't needed up front.
And communications.
And communications.
Many people have the idea that we all fought out of permanent bases out there.
That's not true.
We had permanent bases, and we fought where it was demanded, and we weren't directly tied to those bases at all.
But when we first got there, of course, we had one brigade in that area, the 1st Airborne Division, one U.S. brigade, and there were, as I recall, initially three Vietnamese divisions in that area.

three or four and they've been a great threat that the North Vietnamese were going to take this area and so that's one reason we went rather hurriedly to get into this fight and tell you the truth that first I was there a year and a half in that first period there was
plenty of enemy to be found and fought.
And I'm talking about North Vietnamese divisions.
And there was also a couple of Viet Cong regiments, uniformed regiments, in the area.
And the Viet Cong guerrilla really didn't figure significantly in our operations for that year and a half I was in the division.
Mostly it was against the North Vietnamese regulars.
Mostly it was against the North Vietnamese regulars and their major Viet Cong
How well did your helicopters work in combat?
Very well.
We didn't really have any serious problems other than one.
We found in the dry season, it gets very dry.
You know, they have the rainy season and the dry season.
And when it gets very dry, the dust was a problem.
And we had the same problem
that the helicopter force in the raid on Tehran had.
And we licked it.
How'd you do it?
Well, actually, the technical representatives of the Bell helicopter, I think, as I recall, were the main contributors.
But basically, it was by putting shields so that the dust wouldn't get in there.
The dust and dirt and grime.
And so I was amazed that this happened
helicopters in Iran after the experience, and they had I'm sure the same experience as the Marines in Vietnam.
How well did the rockets work on the helicopters?
They were very effective.
The only major deficiency of the rockets were that they were not extremely accurate, so you had to be very careful not to hit our own people.
How about the machine guns and the cannons?
How'd they work?
Oh, well, everything, we were well equipped, extremely well equipped, and for that war, we didn't have any counter battery requirements.

We didn't have any enemy artillery to counter, and so we had quite adequate firepower, and we used firepower a lot because the American forces, I think, have always believed in using firepower instead of infantrymen's lives.
There were some very interesting...

things developed though from a standpoint of tactics with this new capability for example for the artillery which I was commanding initially there and the old doctrine you can place your artillery in defilade that means for example behind the hill
And the basic purpose of that, to simplify it, the basic reason for that is to be masked from the enemy's artillery and observation.
The principle is observation.
Well, we used the tactic in Vietnam of placing the artillery on the mountaintops.
And the reason for that was that we could get on the mountaintops with our helicopter just as easily as we could get in the valleys.
But being on the mountaintops, we could protect ourselves without drawing off the troopers and the infantry to reinforce us while we were serving the artillery, you see, artillery pieces.
And you could command the valley.
And you could command the valley.
That's just one aspect of it.
Of course, in the larger sense, you generally consider that when you commit a division in combat, in the battle, and commit them to action,
you will keep a healthy reserve.
There's no rule of thumb, but any brigade commander would ordinarily keep at least a battalion in reserve.
He may start his offensive with two in reserve.
Similarly, at division level, a division commander would like to have a brigade in reserve or the elements of a brigade, equivalent elements.
But with this air mobile capability, you really could consider any unit

available to be used as a reinforcing force if he was not actually engaged with the enemy because you could go pick him up and maneuver him as a reserve, a counter-attacking forcing, a reinforcing force.
And so we could commit really the vast majority of our combat battalions and companies
without the danger of being too weak in reserve.
So many of those operations were in the vast areas.
It was very seldom that we had a majority of our battalions in contact with the enemy at any given time.
So I think that gives some hint at the influence that this air mobility had on tactics.
Did you go out on the maneuver?
Or did you usually stay at the headquarters trying to direct and plan the maneuvers?

The headquarters, as assistant division commander for operations, I was usually in my helicopter over the action or we'd have a light command post ahead, division command post on the ground, but I'd seldom get back to the base where the main division headquarters was.
But that helicopter allowed us not only to keep in contact by radio, but you could actually see what was going on.
And that was a great advantage if that higher authority didn't interfere with the subordinates' business.
I always believed in giving the brigade commanders their, letting them make their plan, get their plan approved,
their order and resources do it and let them do it.

But it was a great temptation because a commander, division commander, assistant division commander, brigade commander, could actually be with the operation in the air, see what's going on in many cases.
Of course, in the jungles you can't see that well.
And there was a temptation on the part, to some anyway, to therefore become involved more directly
I tried very religiously not to do that.

I always felt that we had commanders entirely competent, not more competent to conduct that battle on the ground, certainly as competent, and after all you've got to leave the authority where the responsibility is.
Sure, right there.
But the air mobility allowed us to do many of these functions of combat, tactical, logistical,

the intelligence and reconnaissance functions in different ways new ways that weren't possible before for example one day we got orders we were operating around Pleiku got order from our higher commander which was the equivalent of a corps commander to move a brigade near

to an area near Nha Trang, which was about 200, as I recall, about 200 kilometers away from where we were, immediately to reinforce a battalion of ours that had become heavily engaged with a large enemy force and which that immediately reinforced.

As I recall we got that instruction about 10 o'clock in the morning and before sundown that afternoon we were 200 miles away with the assault elements of a brigade in contact with the enemy relieving the commander who was under fire.
That's fantastic.

and then by nightfall those caribou transport aircraft were landing one after the other with supplies and ammunition and we had that brigade closed before midnight and a full brigade on the ground fighting before the next sunrise with its necessary support elements there which is fantastic
And we did that sort of thing.
We had the capability to do that sort of thing.
That was sort of an emergency situation.
And if you choose the way you do things, you can do them a little more calmly and a little more detailed planning, but it can be done.
It can be done very successfully.
We always felt that even if the entire division was operating three brigades and we needed to

make a significant tactical reach we could get a brigade another 25 kilometers out and continue complete support because we had that ability to move and resupply with air and you didn't have to have a road to get there that's for sure now when you were in the air I suppose you were shot at quite a bit weren't you
Was your helicopter hit?
Oh, we were often shot, and occasionally we got hit.
I never was hit.
The nearest, there was a hole shot right next to me in the door of my helicopter, and I got a little prick, but I didn't consider that a wound.
But nevertheless, this was commonplace, of course.
I remember seeing one of our battalion commanders land, and I landed behind him.
We were going to
got together for a chat, and he had 30-some-odd bullet holes in his helicopter, and he was still flying.
My goodness.
I recall very well.
You know, the greatest difficulty encountered in selling the concept of this helicopter, basically helicopter-equipped division, equipped for mobility, was its vulnerability to anti-aircraft.
And, of course...
Selling it to the Pentagon, you mean?
Yeah, so for a decision in the Pentagon and toward the other senior army people up through the channels, a helicopter is a Baltimore machine.
And when you're taking the helicopter right down to the ground to discharge troops, for example, a .45 pistol is a pretty good anti-aircraft weapon.
Certainly a rifle is.
Certainly a machine gun is.
You don't have to have the

sophisticated missiles and everything but many people in looking at this vulnerability question lose sight of the what is the synergenics we call it of the situation where you've got support of all kinds
of this group of helicopters we're going to assume we're going to put into an area.
You've got fire support.
You've got reconnaissance ahead of them to see where the enemy is and to watch to see that he doesn't come in.
You've got the surprise effect of the tactics of coming along just at the treetops, and strangely enough, you won't hear that helicopter until he's right on you.
You won't hear a group of them until he's right there.

and then all of a sudden swim you're down on the air you've selected to land your troops on and you're away and so we're not nearly as vulnerable as you'd think and you say well you didn't have those big anti-aircraft guns and missiles there well that's true the enemy did bring in the uh 20 millimeter anti-aircraft and some of their anti-aircraft weapons later on they gave us more trouble that was after I left
But we tested against our own Hawk missile and we could fly under their radar and we could actually destroy them before they could get a shot off of them according to those experiments.
Anyway, it works.
I think it would work in Europe.
I'm absolutely convinced that every Corps commander in Europe should have one of these divisions or at least a brigade with those capabilities of the Air Assault Division in his force.
They're great for reconnaissance.
They're great to
for flanking operations.
They're great for delaying operations.
They're just great for any raid that requires surprise, swiftness, and reach.
But in Vietnam, I recall at the time I left, we kept pretty careful check and records of the aircraft losses, of course, and even the hits.
Those were reported data, just like casualties.
So many hits,
So many aircraft knocked down, so many aircraft lost, if lost.
One of the beautiful things about a helicopter is that you can disable the engine, but you can still get down safely by auto rotation, it's called.
It takes a good pilot, of course, to do that.
We had splendid pilots.
But as I recall, we had a hit.
for every 750 sorties on the average for the year and a half I was there.
And it doesn't take many hours to fly 750 sorties with 450 aircraft.
We had an aircraft downed every- these 750s hang together- every

2,750 sorties and we had an aircraft lost every 27,500 sorties by means lost and once the helicopter down we usually if we landed it safely we usually recover it and repair it see well how does that so that's not too that's not too vulnerable oh that's pretty good those figures got worse of course when the enemy did bring in his anti-aircraft
And how does that compare to other aircraft?
I really can't tell you that but I know that these are startling statistics when you look back at the predictions that were made you know based on the suspected vulnerability of these aircraft.
Okay you've listed a lot of the benefits of using

the helicopters what were your main problems in Vietnam besides the fact that you'd get hit like any other aircraft the main problems in Vietnam were very clear became very clear I uh was sent home on leave uh no this is I'm not talking just about I'm talking about with the use of the helicopter now we'll get to the problems of all Vietnam oh with the use of the helicopter well uh
Your major problems, of course, were maintenance problems.
Aircraft are sort of difficult to maintain in any case.
Sure, absolutely.
But you just have to rest them enough that you can get their prescribed maintenance in for them.
And that's a very important thing for a commander to consider.
The pilots can fly longer than the aircraft, really, when you consider it.

over a period of days now we're talking about so that was one thing ensuring that we met the maintenance schedules and if we needed parts we often had to wait too long for parts it's just a terribly complex thing there's so many parts involved it's a very difficult thing to maintain a stock or have it in the next depot available to you what you need every day sure

so we would often wind up with more helicopters on deadline waiting maintenance because of parts and therefore this creates a problem because it reduces your effective strength really if you don't have those aircraft so it's something we fought all the time and improved all the time and got better and I think we did a pretty good job a limitation of the helicopter course is its inability to be navigated in closed weather and
We never really got into a serious situation, dangerous situation because of that.
But I recall we had a very careful plan for a surprise assault on the Anlao Valley that was delayed for more than 24 hours because of weather.
And we lost our surprise and therefore lost our enemy who got out of the valley before we got there.
we had a plan that we'd hoped would bottle him up in that valley and just destroy a major element of the North Vietnamese division there.
That's an example of what it can cost you.
But there weren't any insurmountable problems.
It operated very, very well.
Okay, then let's go on to some other issues in Vietnam.
General Westmoreland said that the war was the most technologically fought war in the history of warfare.
What other technological advances did you have that you thought were helpful?
Well, there was one significant one that I should mention not with a problem.
It's always a problem to get enough intelligence.
Any battlefield commander wants more intelligence.
Sure.
And, of course,
The North Vietnamese and Viet Cong, it was rather difficult, particularly the North Vietnamese, to get intelligence on them.
That was timely.
So I suppose that one of the technological capabilities that was most helpful was the electronic intelligence capability.
Fulfilled a very, very important function.
It never brings this intelligence to complete fruition, but it helped a great deal.
I think the- What specifically in the electronics field?
Well, I don't think we can get specific on that.
It's basically getting information by electronic means.
Alright.
Would you cut that off for me?
I hear something.
Another technological area that

of course the aircraft were a tremendous step forward and we were the only division initially that had these all these helicopters assigned organically in other words we had them for use every day but every division in Vietnam had helicopters made available to it sure from supporting units to do go and conduct operations and then the helicopter go back to the parent unit that's quite a different thing because they couldn't
depend on them all the time.
I would add to technological advances that the matter of the use of computers and allied equipment, particularly in the logistics field, that was very significant.
But, of course, I think what the statements that General Westmoreland made
probably quite true, but we would expect the next time we go to war to be technologically even further advanced.
That's a function of this technological revolution we're in.
General Westmoreland, of course, was the Supreme American commander.
Vietnam.
What were your workings with him?
How often did you see him?
Well, we saw General Westmoreland at least once a week at our division.
He came to that division and visited the troops and kept abreast of what we were accomplishing, what we had ahead of us, and we saw him often.
What's your opinion of him?
Can you describe him?
Well, General Westmoreland, as you know,
had been and was an outstanding man among his peers from the time
